content.description:
Quality crack climbing with a spicy slot and a lovely belay perch at the finish.

 Start on the ledges at the base of the cliff and climb cracks to gain the obvious slot about 60' up. Push through the slot - watch for crumbly rock here - to better cracks above. Climb further up and right under roofs (dirty, loose rock) or make a few moves to gain Excalibur above the cedar tree. Finish on the summit ledges climber's left of the Rickety Pinnacle.
content.protection: Standard rack. The bolt is worthless. 70m rope to rappel as per Excalibur. Watch those ends!
content.location: On the left side of the crack riddled face left of the Lost Arrow pinnacle, between the enticing arete Bigger than Jesus and the pillar of Excalibur. Look for the slot mentioned in the description

content.description: It seemed pretty obviously the best line. Wander up the "west" face (facing the road) to the top.I did this years ago using the Mellor's guidebook, so forgive if details are hazy. Look it up in the new "Lawyer-Hass" book, but I remember it being a neat little climb. I forget whether we knew we were on the "False" or whether I actually started up thinking it was the "true" Lost Arrow, then soon realized my error since the climbing was so easy. Afterward we walked over and did the "true" Lost Arrow.
content.location: This is located on the False Arrow Face. There's a fine diagram on page 272 of the 2nd edition "Lawyer-Hass" book.Take the path towards the Spider's Web. About 400-500 ft in take the right branch. Stay left if the path branches again. My recollection is the False Arrow Face sort of dominates the immediate field of view.

content.description: A fun crack climb.  Climb the wide crack to the large cedar.

Supposedly this is where the first ascentionists of the Lost Arrow threw the rope from. It is far from an outstanding route, but provides a better alternative to the 3rd class gully if one is trying to reach Rickety Pinnacle.  

  Scramble up the blocky rock near a huge orange flake to the notch behind Lost Arrow. Climb up past an old ring into the orange left-facing corner. Climb the corner, making liberal use of good holds out left.
content.protection: Takes good pro. There is a tree with slings at the top for rappelling.
content.location: This route begins from the notch behind and to climber's right of the Lost Arrow. Decent can be made by rappelling from the tree at the top or down-climbing the loose, vegetated gully to the right.

content.description:
This is the small pinnacle at the top of the wall above the Lost Arrow. It is worth doing once due to the rarity of formations like this in the area and the spectacular positioning above Chapel Pond Pass.  

  Once at the base, step up ledges until you can grab the top. Mantle up and enjoy the view.
content.protection: When I climbed it, I didn't see the need to place any pro on the pinnacle. There are really only one or two 5th class moves anyway. If you're really worried about it, there is a horizontal about 2 feet below the top that looks like it would take some gear. There are no anchors on top.
content.location:
To reach the base of the pinnacle, either climb the 3rd class gully to the right, or climb the route Rope Toss Wall. Other easy technical climbs exist that can also deposit you near the base of the pinnacle. 

  To descend, downclimb the pinnacle back to the notch. From there, either downclimb the 3rd class gully to climber's right, or rappel off a tree with a fixes anchor.

content.description: Thin face climbing up a series of finger cracks gains the roof.  There is a break in the roof directly above the finger cracks, and an actual right leaning crack about 5' left of this where the roof line breaks into a left facing corner.  Adirondack Rock seems to say go straight up the middle, but we didn't find any hold there and instead used a right-leaning crack on the left side of the roof.  Above the roof the crack was full of vegetation and debris so the fun doesn't stop.  Another 15' gains a birch tree for belay.
content.protection: Small rack for the face, #3/#4 for the roof/crux.  We used a Black Alien and brassies on the face.
content.location: 15' right of Short Order.  You can set a TR on this by topping out Short Order.

climbs.name: Lost Arrow: Southeast Face
climbs.fa: 1950 via rope toss and tyrolian Dave Bernays & Stanley Smith, FFA unknown

content.description: I did this years ago using the Mellor's guidebook, so forgive if details are hazy. Look it up in the new "Lawyer-Hass" book, but I remember it being a worthwhile climb. The crux, if I recall correctly, used small wire nuts for pro. I put this in as a 5.8 since that's it's listing in the current book, but my recollection is it might have been a bit easier, or I might have been climbing very well that day.There were (are?) no bolts on top. I remember I tied a large loop of rope (or long sling) around the whole top for the belay “tie in“ at the top.We descended as follows: The second ties the end of the rope to a tree, such that the rope will run as straight as possible from the tree to the top of the spire. Then he/she ties into the middle of the rope with a fig-8 and double locking biners. When both climbers are on top, both untie from the rope (so I guess a long sling is best for the tie-in) and the leader's end of the rope is dropped down the back side of the spire until the rope is taught with the tree. Then the climbers rap single-strand off the back-side. (Hint- With an "ATC-type device" if you double up on the biners you get more friction when you rap single strand.)
content.protection: Std Rack....small wire nuts for thin stuff
content.location: There's a fine diagram on page 272 of the 2nd edition "Lawyer-Hass" book.Take the path towards the Spider's Web. About 400-500 ft in take the right branch. We managed to hit the "False Lost Arrow" first, (a very pleasant climb)  then we circled left to the "true" Lost Arrow. The 5.8 route is on the "south" face, facing towards the Northway.

content.description: Very nice crack and corner climbing on this one, and with good rock quality and protection. Better than the acclaimed Rockaholic or Mr Rogers Neighborhood, in my opinion, or at least more interesting and scenic. And likely harder too...Scramble to the base of a left-facing corner. Up this to a ledge, then up the obvious crack, past a cedar tree, to the summit ledges to a tree belay (same as Virgin Sturgeon)Rappel from the cedar just below the top (70m rope minimum) or descend loose third class past the Rickety Pinnacle.
content.protection: Standard rack. #4 C4 optional. The midroute cedar currently has no anchor, as was described in Adirondack Rock.
content.location: Locate the left facing corner on the crack riddled face, left of the Lost Arrow pinnacle

content.description: These are the broken collection of cliffs between Spider's Web and Upper Washbowl. While there are some high quality routes, the abundance of scree and talus and general loose rock makes this area much less appealing than the many other high quality cliffs in this region. This area is home to the only free-standing pinnacles in the Adirondacks.
